body_html: @apaszke IMO if we have more than 1 inf then we should return nan for all since we have no idea how to compare between different infs. However if we have only 1 inf (e.g. a number too big to represent with float format), then we know that it is the same quantity on both sides when we do the division, and it should return the one hot representation showing where the inf is.
body_text: @apaszke IMO if we have more than 1 inf then we should return nan for all since we have no idea how to compare between different infs. However if we have only 1 inf (e.g. a number too big to represent with float format), then we know that it is the same quantity on both sides when we do the division, and it should return the one hot representation showing where the inf is.
body: @apaszke IMO if we have more than 1 `inf` then we should return `nan` for all since we have no idea how to compare between different `inf`s. However if we have only 1 `inf` (e.g. a number too big to represent with `float` format), then we know that it is the same quantity on both sides when we do the division, and it should return the one hot representation showing where the `inf` is.
